title: Letters we Love
content:
The companion thread to [Glyphs that Gall](http://web.archive.org/web/20120927043434/http:/typophile.com/node/30598), as proposed by Matthew Desmond. I have to say, I can't think of any letter shapes that I'm particularly enchanted by, perhaps because I love letters that blend with the rest in the font. Perhaps I should create a third thread about great fonts in general, but surely that topic's been exhausted in other threads. Can anyone link to them?

Anyway, for this topic, pattyfab suggested the ampersand of Caslon Italic. Quite fab indeed, Patty.

one of my favorite letters is the "a' from Catull

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120927043434im_/http:/typophile.com/files/a_6358.gif)

Jackie, that is one gorgeous glyph.

But 'glyph love', as Hrant has noted, can be a trap for type designers.

As Mario Feliciano said to me at TypeCon 2005: "You don't want beautiful letters, you want beautiful words."

Looking at sample words of Catull on MyFonts, the 'a' has 'color' problems, leaving a gap in the NE corner compared to the other lc letters. So the Catull a is exquisite, but a problem within the font.

Caslon Italic's ampersand is my favorite.

Gill Sans Italic's p.
Johnston's M, see avatar. The beauty is in the function and legibility. Compare it to the nasty Helvetica and ugly, splayed Futura.

This is Elegant Grotesk by Stempel, from Gustav Möhring.  
Its designed 1928 and comparing it with other fonts of this epoche I feel this one as one of the most beautiful Grotesk.

I love all the lower case letters within the bold version:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120927043434im_/http:/typophile.com/files/1_3605.jpg)

I don't know if there is a digitalized version of it.  
But its not important for me.

Georg

William,

You would have appreciated seeing Catull set from an Alphatype machine, with a master font that had 6 different point sizes.

When Berthold bought out Alphatype they offered us some of their library - redrawn for the Alphatype. I was the only shop in New York City to have Catull. I loved that font. One of the publishing houses (I think it was Carol Publishing or Pinnacle or maybe even Ballantine) had an author who was producing romance books every few months. (Not quite a Barbara Cartland, but direct competition.) I convinced the art director to use Catull for the covers. A few years later (and many art directors later) I received a call asking what the face was -- and how come Cardinal, Photoletter, Haber, etc. didn't have it... it was so nice having an "exclusive."

And WTF must have one of Adobe's original fonts. There were so many problems with their releases. I laugh how folks think "professional" fonts are so great -- even though I own Adobe fonts -- I keep remembering when I first bought the library in the late 1980s. They told me I could sell the whole library when I was done with it. Nice of them... (I don't know if you remember this, they also gave me all the printer fonts on an 80mg hard disk that fit my Compugraphic imagesetter... making it just a little bit faster at the time.)

Very interesting, Georg. Licko must have been inspired by Elegant while designing her [Base fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20120927043434/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startrow=1&records=&currpage=1&totalrecords=8&displayfontid=E.10266.0.0&fontRendererText=abcdeghijmnop).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120927043434im_/http:/typophile.com/files/loType_g_4178.jpg)

I love the g's too from some of the Hellenic wide fonts - it's as if they didn't know quite what to do so they just went wwwwiiiiidddddeeeeee.

I think the g is a glyph to have fun with.
